Sure, here are three authors who discuss Plato's critique of writing in "Phaedrus":

1. 18th century: Jean-Jacques Rousseau - In his "Confessions", Rousseau refers to Plato's critique of writing and argues that writing has caused people to forget the art of oral storytelling.
2. 19th century: Friedrich Nietzsche - In his "Twilight of the Idols", Nietzsche discusses Plato's idea that writing would lead to forgetfulness and argues that it has instead created a culture of memory that is stronger than ever before.
3. 20th century: Walter J. Ong - In his book "Orality and Literacy: The Technologizing of the Word", Ong provides an in-depth analysis of Plato's critique of writing and argues that the shift from orality to literacy had a profound impact on human culture and thought.
